name.text: Finding the central tendency for ungrouped data

questiontext.text:
The number of cement bags manufactured daily at the Simba Cement Factory over a period of 30 days is recorded below:

{@raw_data@}

Analyze this ungrouped data to determine the following measures of central tendency:

a) Mean: Calculate the mean daily production.
Mean = [[input:ans1]] bags [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

b) Median: Determine the median number of bags produced.
Median = [[input:ans2]] bags [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]

c) Mode: Identify the mode of the dataset.
(Note: If there is more than one mode, enter them as a set, e.g., {450, 460}).
Mode = [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]] [[feedback:prt3]]

generalfeedback.text:
a) Mean

The mean is the sum of all observations divided by the total number of observations (\(N\)).

\( \bar{x} = \frac{\sum x}{N} \) \( \bar{x} = \frac{{@sum_x@}}{30} \) \( \bar{x} \approx {@decimalplaces(mean_val, 2)@} \text{ bags} \)

b) Median

To find the median, we first arrange the data in ascending order:

{@sorted_data@}

Since there are \( N=30 \) observations (an even number), the median is the average of the two middle values (the \(15^{\text{th}}\) and \(16^{\text{th}}\) terms).

  • \(15^{\text{th}}\) value: {@term15@}
  • \(16^{\text{th}}\) value: {@term16@}
\( \text{Median} = \frac{{@term15@} + {@term16@}}{2} = {@median_val@} \text{ bags} \)

c) Mode

The mode is the value that appears most frequently in the dataset. To see this clearly, we can tally the frequency of each production amount:

{@freq_table_rows@}
Production (Bags) Frequency

From the table, the highest frequency is {@max_freq@}.

The value(s) with this frequency: {@ta_mode@}.

questiondescription.text:
Daniel Murunga

In this question, you are provided with 30 raw data points representing the daily production of cement bags at a factory. You are required to analyze this ungrouped data to calculate the mean daily production, determine the median, and identify the mode(s) of the dataset.
